importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the most recent update on the flooding situation in Mexico, reflecting the ongoing impact and emergency response efforts as of that day.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred over the previous week, establishing the temporal scope of the disaster and the duration of the emergency response efforts.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding affecting five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing.
Veracruz recorded 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro one death.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Over 100,000 homes have been affected; some homes near rivers were reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
Thousands of military troops, including Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist in rescue and relief operations.
The flooding was caused by remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which led to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply in the affected states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating the extreme rainfall intensity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has suffered a major flooding disaster resulting in at least 64 fatalities across five states, with 65 people still missing. The worst-hit areas are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths). The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which brought extreme rainfall—peaking at 280mm in Cerro Azul and 286mm in Cuetzalan del Progreso. Thousands of military personnel from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to assist in search and rescue, deliver food and water, and restore basic services. Over 100,000 homes were affected, with some structures destroyed or rendered uninhabitable. Despite the scale of the disaster, officials noted that there were no prior meteorological warnings predicting the intensity of the rainfall, raising questions about early warning systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
